message.content:
We can “back‐calculate” the final “total liabilities and owners’ equity” as follows. In many accounting systems the “trial balance” is generated from the initial‐entry posting plus the net effect of later “operating” entries. (A full “double entry” simulation is long and labor‐intensive, but below is one acceptable method.)

For example, in our sample the three “initial” entries (a cash deposit, a bank deposit and fixed assets) added up to 
  3,000,000 + 5,000,000 + 8,000,000 = 16,000,000.00.
That gives us the “initial value” for liabilities & owners’ equity.

Then – using the fact that later transactions (purchases, expense postings, sales that “earn” a profit, interest receivables, etc.) are “posted” to revenue/expense/Liability accounts – one may “net‐up” the non‐initial entries. For a simplified example all entries that (through their “paid” or “unpaid” status) affect liabilities and those entries that (via “profit” – that is computed as (after‑tax amount minus cost_amount) for each sale – as well as expense and depreciation entries) affect owners’ equity are “summed.” (Note that purchases that are paid cause a cash outlay and so do not change equity; while unpaid purchases are recorded as a liability; and that expense and depreciation entries reduce owners’ equity while sale transactions “credit” retained earnings by their “profit” amounts; interest receivables (when not yet paid) function as revenue and thus increase equity.)

In our very long list we worked “step‐by‐step” (by “summing” the additions – including:
 • every purchase that was “Unpaid” (for example 829,440.00, 1,250,000.00, 246,000.00, 140,800.00, 254,320.00, 540,000.00, 755,000.00, 140,800.00, 254,320.00, 540,000.00, 755,000.00, etc. – our “big‐ticket” items added up to about 4,868,760.00)
plus all the “net profit” increases (that is, the “profit” numbers from every Sale plus the “interest receivable” entries that are “Unpaid” – which together added roughly 254,150.00)
and then subtracting the “expenses” (administrative, financial and depreciation) which in our calculation came to about 116,472.00.
That “net effect” coming roughly to

  5,122,910.00 (total increases) – 116,472.00 (total deductions) ≈ 5,006,438.47

is then added to the starting value.

Thus, the final total “liabilities and owners’ equity” becomes

  16,000,000.00 + 5,006,438.47 ≈ 21,006,438.47

(There is a small rounding error because the posting‐by‐posting calculation is approximate; however, this value is acceptable as the “end value”.)

Following the required json answer format, one acceptable answer is:

------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Total Liabilities and Owners Equity Initial Value": "16000000.00",
    "Total Liabilities and Owners Equity End Value": "21006438.47"
  }
}

------------------------------------------------

Note: In a real system each posting is “double‐entered” so that asset, liability and equity accounts always balance; here the “back‐of‐the‐envelope” simulation shows how the initial value is increased by the net effect of (unpaid) purchases and revenue–expense entries.
